Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Development of an Interactive Web-based Dashboard to Track COVID-19 in Real-time

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: <p>This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) grant will be used to support the management and development of the COVID-19 online interactive dashboard hosted by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University. The dashboard was first released publicly on January 22, 2020 to visualize and track the COVID-19 outbreak in real-time, and has since served as the prominent centralized source of COVID-19 epidemiological data throughout the COVID-19 outbreak to date. The dashboard illustrates the location and number of confirmed cases, deaths and recoveries for all affected countries, with additional features added over time. Further, all the data collected and displayed is made freely available to researchers, public health authorities and the general public in a GitHub repository, along with the feature layers of the dashboard. The availability of this data at the initial stages of the outbreak enabled the public health and research community to implement modeling tools, specifically the calibration of parameters for estimating transmission and spread at the earliest stages of the outbreak, when more formal situation reports were lagging, and thus gain a better understanding of the disease characteristics early on, which allowed for evidenced based decision making. Further, members of the public health community, including national and local level governmental organizations and public health offices around the world, continue to rely on the dashboard for informing, planning, and decision making regarding public safety, such as clinical staffing and resource allocation.</p><br/><br/><p>Given the popularity and impact of the dashboard to date, there is a need to continue to maintain it, and further build out its capabilities. Specifically, this includes the collection and curation process to capture data from a broader set of sources, enabling an increase in the spatial resolution (ideally to the city level) of the reporting. Introduction of additional features, including health-related context and confidence measures for the data and information presented, will increase the dashboard's utility in supporting awareness and decision-making. Additional model and analytic research and development will enhance detection and classification, and more broadly, relative risk determination of events of concern from all sourced health related data. Longer term, systems engineering activities associated with this development will ensure an enduring capability established, vetted, and well-used prior to the next potential pandemic. Thus, the research efforts are critical to provide an early-warning system for future public health events, and help inform control measures in the current and future outbreaks.</p><br/><br/><p>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.</p>

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report 

Award Title: RAPID: Development of an Interactive Web-based Dashboard to Track COVID-19 in Real-time
Federal Award ID: 2028604
Report Submission Period: 05/01/2021 to 04/30/2022
PI: Lauren Gardner
Recipient Organization: Johns Hopkins University

This project has supported the continued management and development of the COVID-19 online interactive dashboard hosted by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University during the COVID-19 pandemic. The dashboard provides a state of the art, centralized, real-time reporting and open data sharing system, and thus enabled real-time predicting, preventing, and tracking of COVID-19 disease around the world.

To date, there been over 220 billion queries (e.g., interactions and data requests) on the dashboard, and over 3 billion page views, which are accumulated from almost every country around the world.  The Dashboard has been featured and the data used to feed the visualizations by multiple major media organizations worldwide. Individuals have accessed and relied on the data to make informed decisions and manage their own personal exposure risk.  Governments have relied on the data to guide evidence-based public health response for cities, states, and countries. Additionally, the data have been used in applications ranging from determining where best to hold vaccine trials, to supporting companies in identifying the set of factories and offices to keep operational and to time the re-opening of others.

Maintaining the data collection efforts supporting the dashboard has required multiple engineering innovations and many creative solutions to significant challenges, which have been developed by the team of scientist working under Dr. Gardner, including PhD, Masters and undergraduate students, as well as professional software developers, computer and data scientists, and systems engineers. We have had to continuously adapt the dashboard architecture to incorporate large quantities of data from disparate sources, with highly variable data structures. To ensure the data quality, we developed (and continue to refine) a novel anomaly detection system from scratch, designed to screen the thousands of automatically collected data points updated on the dashboard hourly, and uses a custom logic, specific to time and place, to identify and hold back those data that exceed certain thresholds which have to be manually validated. Similar such innovations were required to address changes in the data being reported, scale-up of the web-based resource to service billions of hits per day, and continued development of visualization tools that help the public to better understand the trends. Students and supporting staff have presented on our groups efforts in dozens of high impact, professional forums around the world.

In addition to serving as a mechanism for public awareness of the pandemic in real time through the interactive visualization, the dashboard is linked with a free, open data product that includes each data point ever shown on the map. This the data set will serve as an invaluable resource for retrospective scientific analysis of COVID-19, enabling a better understanding of infectious disease transmission and preparation for future pandemics.

Inspired by the JHU COVID dashboard and data sharing efforts, the dashboard concept has been widely replicated around the world by domestic and foreign governments, media outlets, private enterprises and higher education institutions. An international network of related dashboards is expected to become a permanent fixture in how nations improve coordinated responses to future pandemics and epidemics. This essential tool has changed the way the world views the COVID-19 pandemic and revolutionized how infectious diseases will be regarded in the future. Billions of people have likely benefitted from this tool, whether directly from accessing the data or indirectly from life-saving public policies relying on this information.


Last Modified: 07/29/2022
Modified by: Lauren M Gardner
